reviewText:
Early Access Review

As much as I wanted to love Wild Season I just couldn't.

This was another Kickstarter backed game that I threw my money at the second I saw it. I've played every Harvest Moon since the first and I've been waiting a long time for someone to bring something similar to PC and when I saw it happening by fans of the original Harvest moons I was more than excited.

I first tried the game in Alpha stage when it was pretty much unplayable, but the involvement from the developers kept me interested so periodically I would drop back in and try it out over and over but that seems to be my problem. If you were to ask me how the game has advanced since Alpha I couldn't tell you. The controls are unbearable, and I mean to the point you want to pull your hair out. Figuring out which button does what will put you in the mood to rage and that's before you even get into the gameplay. (It seems on the last update they've informed us they have hired two new members of the team to sort these control issues out so hopefully this could be changing in the near future)
Once I managed to work out the controls well enough to input my name and such I was forced to watch the unskippable prologue bit before being led to my farm. Then the game crashed.
Loaded it up again, and the game crashed on the menu screen. Now I've found crashing to be a frequent problem for this game which is expected in early access, but not being able to skip the start up dialogue makes it really, really unappealing for me. Now when it crashes before I've had the chance to save it I don't even bother trying again.
Now I'm sure the actual gameplay is great, following the blogs and podcasts you can see how much effort the developers are putting into it. There are tonnes of villagers, crops, animals and what seems to be a great (and mysterious) story but I can't see myself ever loving the game.

I think what I found appealing about Harvest Moon and similar games was the simplicity. Though the tasks could be seen as repetitive for boring the game kept you playing. This game seems to lack that charm.
There are too many small bothersome things that bug me as I play. Having to constantly hold a button to run, not being able to change direction when running without first stopping, animations that seem to go on far too long, unfriendly villagers and the lack of overall polish in the game all put me off.
My biggest problem is the game feels like it's made by an amateur indie studio. I'm sure there are loads of people out there who love this game, I'm just not one of them. For me the game doesn't feel like it's in Beta which makes me a little worried for the final state BUT I will be keeping my eye on it and I don't see it as a wasted investment because I know one day when it's released I will give it another try.

I finally see why the developer of Stardew Valley has waiting so long to release his game. I think games like this need to be played in their full state or not at all and despite the fact there are a tonne of good reviews I honestly think if the game was as good as those people were saying they would have clocked in far more than 1-2 hours. I play Harvest Moon for 3-4 hours at a single time.

Maybe by release Wild Season will be worth the money but right now, I'd advise you to hold onto your money and wait until it's out of development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: Received a key for review purposes

One thing you have to realize about Wild Season is that it's very much an Early-Access game. At its current state, the game is pretty buggy and needs a lot of fine-tuning. Currently the gameplay and controls are a bit frustrating. This game is a farming life sim, yet I found it difficult to work on my farm for extended periods of time because of how slow it took for my character to perform actions. Sometimes it took more than a couple of seconds for my character to pick up weeds or crops and then put them away in my bag. Even working on a 3x3 plot is time-staking. This is a shame because I was looking more forward to the farming-sim aspect of the game than the RPG/ Visual Novel aspect of the game.

The controls also need to be better mapped AND/OR better noted ingame. WASD for movement was fairly easy to figure out but J K L for actions was not as obvious. This should have been told from the beginning, not an hour into the game.

There are also a lot of immoveable cutscenes from the very start. I understand this is also a visual novel and an RPG so there are bound to be many cutscenes to move along the story, However I wish the game wouldn't heavily depend on cutscenes to progress. Even just letting me open the door myself when someone knocks on my house door, or entering a store and walking towards the NPCs myself would be better than waiting constantly for the cutscenes to end and for me to finally do something and move around. All the cutscenes made me feel very constrained and I would have liked the option to meet the characters at my own pace.

One thing I really like about the game is the story and characters. I'd certainly like to know why the townpeoples are acting so xenophobic and what my farm has to do with anything. Some of the characters are very charming and interesting. Your task is not just maintaining your farm; it also includes building platonic or romantic relationships with your neighbors. But once again while I'd love to explore more into the story's lore and story, the poor controls make it difficult for me to play for a long period of time.

I like the concept of this game, and personally I think this game would be a lot more enjoyable if the developers fixed the controls. However this game needs a lot of work. At the current stage of development, I cannot find myself recommending this game.

Early Access Review

Note: I got a key from the developer for beta testing.

In short: I am quite indecisive about the rating. It is not bad enough to give it a thumbs down but has too many bugs / incomplete features to give it a thumbs up.
So, maybe consider buying this ONLY IF you want to play this game while it is in development AND IF you can get it during a sale.

+ Nice and cute JRPG style graphics
+ Day and night transition.
+ There *seemed* to be plenty to do (though I didn't get to do much during my playthrough).
+ A lot of NPCs, which hopefully will be woven into the story.
+ Interesting storyline (for me, this is the main selling point).
+ Dialogues with NPCs add to the suspense.
+ Relaxing background music

- Buggy. Eg. Invisible characters with dialogues.
- Sometimes 'Esc' doesn't bring up the menu. Had to Alt-F4 to quit.
- Weird one: I cannot get the character to go to sleep? None of my action keys worked.
- Keystrokes sometimes do not register.
- Non-intuitive controls. Should make use of LMB and RMB.
- Unclear about save function. Does it auto-save? If not, where is the manual save button? Though to be fair, my game resumed from where it left off when I last quit.
- No clear quests outline (so I just wandered around town).
- Very pricey at $30 base price. Especially IF the devs decide to increase the price of the final product.

The game is still in EA so I understand it's a work in progress and taking this into consideration, I won't give it a thumbs down. I think it has potential to be good game if and when the bugs are fixed.

However, I can only recommend it if you can get it at a discounted price ($30 base price at time of writing) because I don't think the gameplay can justify the price tag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: A key was provided for me to beta test the game and write an honest review
I would like to apologize for my previous review, to those who aren’t satisfied with it and to those who doesn’t agree to what I wrote. After spending more time with this game, and figuring out a few stuffs, including how the save system works I’ve decided to revise my review, and hopefully this will correct my previous mistakes.

Plot  – The story starts slow, it does take time before you see how it unfolds. The first part is quite too long for an introduction, you’ll be reading many dialogue lines before you could get your hands on the game and start playing. You can see notification on the right that you have completed a quest, but there is no actual UI that shows what your quest was or what your current one is. But there is a journal that shows your progress instead. So far as I’ve noticed, there is an event or happening at least once each day. So other than taking care of your farm, you’ll have something to look forward to the next day.

There are times that the people you have met in town before, will no longer remember you once you talked to them again, therefore resetting the conversation.

Graphics and Sounds  - The game was made in Unity, and so far it isn't that heavy in terms of graphics. My laptop can handle the game, but there are some noticeable lags and fps drops at some points of the game. Graphical errors also appear during conversations, i.e. an NPC goes through a wall or an NPC cannot be seen physically but they do have a dialogue. I’m not sure if it’s intentional that you can go through the NPCs, but it does take time trying to chase the NPC you’re trying to talk to. There are also invisible blocks that don’t let you pass through on the edges near the exit of the map. B

The game starts with a nostalgic soundtrack, for me it reminds me of the game I used to play on my GBA. It is a nice addition that a different soundtrack plays on different areas, but other than that, I suggest that they add an ambient sound as that would make players more comfortable rather than just having a music playing over and over again.

Environment and Design  – The game may look like a mobile game, but that doesn’t mean it’s a bad one. The areas are well designed, enough clutter so that it doesn’t feel flat or too boring in the eyes. Probably one way to improve this, is allow the players to inspect the objects in front of them and maybe just show a dialogue or description about that specific object.

On the world map, I think there should be a label to see what area that is. And maybe add some signs on how to get there, because I personally had a hard time going to the port. I didn’t know that there is a passage on the east side of the town.  But other than that, I think the areas are placed ideally.

Gameplay  – It’s the game that I’ve been wanting to have on Steam, a casual game that allows you to manage a farm where you can grow some crops, take care of farm animals, do fishing, and as well as mining. And then it also comes with a story, where you get to meet the people who live nearby and participate in different yearly events.

Controls  – The control option states the action keys, but it does not tell what it exactly does in-game. At first, you’ll probably press all keys to figure out its function.  The game also has a delay on registering the keys you’ve pressed, specifically on menus and when doing tasks on your farm i.e. tilling, watering, harvesting, picking up, etc. And with the gameplay this game offers, it is probably the best to play this game using a controller.

Conclusion  – Sure, this game has its downs but nonetheless it is still a great game. Besides the game is still in Early Access, and so far, the developer has been very active on the discussion boards. Even if you’re not amused of how the game looks right now, I hope you stay tuned and be updated with upcoming changes.

And for me, a few polishes and fixes this can turn out a very great game.

Early Access Review

Alright, before you criticize me, I'm giving a bad review in early access because I really really gave this game a chance. I followed up on the forums, gave a bunch of my opinions, reported tons of bugs but after so long I feel I have to give this a negative review (might change in the future).

I got this game because I loved Harvest Moon, as probably most of you interested in this game love too. But hold your horses, this is in my opinion, so far, a backward step comparing to HM and the future doesn't look so bright for Wild Season as months since this was released as an Early Access it is still completely unplayable. The developers said even the little story it has in so far will be remade and there isn't anything else to do rather than literaly plant things down.

Months in so far and the single biggest thing people have been asking nonstop on forums is the controller support as keyboard controls have gone from horrible to bad. Still no controller support...

There is nothing to do around. HM revolves around exploration of a magical and charming town/surroundings full of mystical surprises that slowly the player gets to know and unlock. Wild Season is a big emptyness with nothing to unlock or do during your days. I know this is an early access, but even as an early access you should have things to do, whats the point of releasing an early access if you're still in early alpha with no real gameplay?

So basicaly in your very first free day in the game you can explore everything, talk to everyone and still won't even be night time, meaning you will have to go to bed early and all the following days there won't be any point revisiting any of those spots because nothing changes and again, there's literally nothing to do. So you use all your stamina and go rest for the next day.

Updates are in such a slow pace, that in order to fix a major bug, it takes at least two weeks (probably more) to be fixed.
There is a number of annoying little things you can't get around. The game itself seems very unresponsive and slow, hitbox to interact with NPCs is hard to find, so when an NPC is walking around it's almost a challenge to talk to them, can't read most signs, most NPCs are uninteresting and for me it has been more of a drag than a pleasure to play.

So far, comparing to Harvest Moon, a 1999 game, the only progress I noticed were the graphics (which comes with tons of problems/bugs), in other aspects, from what I experienced, this is a step backward.

This review might seem harsh, but I feel it's my responsibility to make sure developers think twice before releasing completely unplayable games so that they make some $$ and don't really deliver what was promised. So DON'T buy this game until it's fully functional and playable because there is a huge chance you will be disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access games always involve a gamble with your money; even with the reduced price tag, it is with great regret that Wild Season remains unenjoyable if not completely unplayable in its current state.

While Wild Season may strike as a mere pastiche of the acclaimed Harvest Moon games at first, there is enough potential here to create the same addictive experience which made its forebears so popular. The graphical presentation is cute enough, but in a more imaginative approach to the genre the backdrop teases a more sinister backbone with its setting and characters.

Unfortunately Wild Season is bedecked with far too many bugs, glitches and control issues to sustain any length of playing time. For those reasons alone, on top of the somewhat demanding fee, Wild Season cannot be recommended.

The positive, however, is that the developers communicate often with customers: they display tireless dedication with their continuous updates, with many of the player feedback being immediately acknowledged and applied in quick fashion. The overall vision of Wild Season is assuredly fun if the developers can iron out the kinks and continue to work towards filling in the major blanks missing in this early access version.

Wild season is basically a farm game with some sim aspects thrown in there. There's a rather mysterious story to keep things moving together, which works alright.

Music sets the mood just fine and the sound effects are on point.
Animation quality is somewhat above your standard indie JRPG quality, but nothing to be exited about (bugs really bother here right now).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wild Season is a story-centric farming simulator with a lot of potential. You just invested all your money into the purchase of a farm which turns out to be not quite what you expected, in a town full of people who clearly do not want you around. You now have to try and restore the farm while figuring out why the community is so hostile towards you.

The art style is well-done and reminiscent of classic jRPG titles. The sprites and characters are beautifully drawn. The music is nice and suits the game very well. Sound effects are also decent and get the job done.

There is a good number of NPCs and locations to visit, friends to be made as well as people trying to convince you to leave town.

The pace of the game is quite slow and while it's okay when working on your farm, people who aren't fans of visual novels will probably be put off by the lengthy dialogues sequences. Between the intro and the tutorial, it will take you over 30 minutes before you can actually start to play on a new game. While it does a good job of setting the back story, this should definitely be reworked to get the player into the game sooner. (You can bypass most of it with the Quick Start menu option, but then you don't get to choose your character's name and characteristics.)

At the time of writing this review, the game is still in early access and a lot of bugs are currently present in the game as well as large chunks of contents missing. Interactions with other NPCs are limited and they don't remember your past conversations between sessions. There's a lot of features mentioned at some point in the game that don't seem to be implemented yet. Also, saving the game doesn't always seem to work so you need to double check if you don't want to have to revert to the last auto-save. The developers appear to be active and are adding depth to the game and fixing bugs, so it look like it's headed in the right way.

Controls currently feel very disconnected. Using the keyboard and mouse doesn't quite feel right, yet when playing with a controller it doesn't feel very responsive. Plus, not everything is currently mapped to the controller so I end up going back and forth between the keyboard and mouse  and the controller. Some actions, like closing an inventory window are mapped to the same button as using the tools, so you often end up spending energy needlessly by swinging your tools around when you simply want to close a dialog.

Overall the game is nice and, with the right tweaking, can really evolve into something worth playing. Right now, I can only recommend this game if you want to support the developer and don't mind playing it in it's unfinished state. The price tag for this game seems quite steep for what you're currently getting and even for the final product, I would expect the sweet spot for a game like this to be around the $20 mark.

I really, really wanted to like this game. I love Harvest Moon, and the idea of Harvest Moon with some lurking, dread secret sounded wonderful to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Impressions Review

Story:

The story seems very nice so far. You play as an inexperienced farm owner, living in a town full of people who are polite, but strangely cold and standoffish.  Why do the townsfolk distrust and dislike you so much? Will they help you with your farm, despite their feelings and your lack of experience?  Will you be able to do this on your own if they don't help? The story is well written, and more than enough to make me want to keep playing.  But there's just so...much...dialogue....   The dialogue text appears on the screen slowly, and I read fast. With no option to speed up the dialogue or skip parts of it, getting through the game's opening can feel like a real chore.  There is however a quick start option, so you can skip the opening scenes completely and go straight to the game.


Gameplay:

It's mostly the typical farm sim stuff:  You plant crops, raise animals, clean up your farm and do other management type chores.  Fans of the genre will feel right at home here, and newcomers will be able to get into it easily.  The tutorials can be a bit wordy, but most game tutorials have that problem, and it's not as bad as many.  I haven't run into any major glitches yet.


Graphics and Sound:

The graphics are very cute, colorful and 16bit-looking. They fit with the gameplay and story very well, and bring in a huge nostalgia factor, for me at least. I feel like I'm playing a Game Boy Advance or SNES again. The music fits too:  Simple, relaxing tunes that make you feel like you're living a country life.


Controls:

I played using a mouse and keyboard, and the controls seem to work well enough.  I did have one pretty frustrating issue:  I started playing in windowed mode, and after going through a good 40 minutes of story, I figured out that about half of the controls weren't working.  I restarted (quickplay this time) in fullscreen, and everything worked fine.


Menu Options:

The game has the option to raise and lower the volume for music and SFX.  You can also change between a few resolutions and play in full screen or windowed.  Some more resolution options might be nice, but I can't think of much else you'd need for a game like this. Again, I hope they add an option to speed up text for dialogue.  Slowly reading through the opening scenes can be a little painful.


Early Access Notes:

Wild Season is currently an Early Access game, meaning there will be bugs and glitches, your save file may or may not get wiped at some point, and things may not always work the way they should.  This is true for ALL early access games!  Sadly, there will be people who buy the game on a whim without understanding what early access is, and give a negative review based on things the devs haven't gotten around to implementing or fixing yet.  Please don't be one of those people!  You should only buy this game if you enjoy the genre, want to support the project, are willing to put up with glitches, and are interested in providing polite feedback and helpful criticism. Early access is for patient and understanding gamers.


Rating:

I won't give a rating on Wild Season yet, since it's an early access game and any rating would likely change based on how the game changes.  I will say that's it's a fun little farming sim with cute graphics, good gameplay, nice music and a entertaining story. There are glitches here and there, probably even some that I haven't seen yet. But looking around, I've found that the devs respond quickly to community posts, and there are updates on a fairly regular basis. More than that, I feel like there's a lot of love and hard work being put into this game, and in my opinion, the effort is worth supporting.

Sad to say, this is the first negative review I have ever written. Hopefully my last.

I want to preface this by saying that I'm an absolute Harvest Moon FANatic. I own nearly all of them, and spent an obscene chunk of my life playing them.

I've always wanted to have a Harvest Moon game on PC as I have a ridiculous amount of consoles and handhelds just trying to keep up with this series of games.

I also want to say that I have very high hopes for Wild Season. I seriously, truly do. But that being said this attempt at bringing a Harvest Moon game to the PC has serious issues that forbid me from recommending this attempt to anyone.

First, the development seems very lackluster and uninspired. Even now the development cycle is going to longer and longer delays in producing any tangible work.

The developers spend most of their time touring around touting the game, but spend very little time ON the game. Their twitch feeds spend the bulk of their time also either just talking about the places they've visited or other games, such as the last one where they spent more time talking about how much they wanted to play Cities Skyline then any interest in the development of their own game.

They're a small indie group trying to charge a Triple A price for a concept in which they have little to no apparent interest in developing, prefering rather to use their current  barely functional mock-up to boastfully party down on the convention circuit. Just where is the money that the backers really going for?

I truly do hope that a good Harvest Moon game does come to the PC, and I honestly do hope that Wild Season, Stardew Valley and World's Dawn does finally break the curse of failed attempts to bring a HM game to PC.

But currently, with the slowing development, erratic developer interest, and money flowing to everything EXCEPT game development I can not, in good faith, recommend this project to any of my fellow Harvest Moon fanatics.

Wild Season is a refreshing take on the farming RPG (think Harvest Moon), with an intriguing story and loveable characters. Normally I only play games with a strong narrative aspect, so the original Harvest Moon games, while fun to me when I was younger, were somewhat difficult for me to stick with because they couldn't hold my interest for long periods of time. I was pleasantly surprised to discover that Wild Season does have an overarching mystery story--I bought the farm and moved into the town like normal, BUT, from the beginning it was pretty clear that a lot of people were UNHAPPY about the fact that I moved in. Some of them even asked me outright to leave, which only makes me more interested to find out what it is they're all hiding! Even so, a lot of the characters are really fun to interact with, and have their own unique personalities and ways of speaking. The dialogue definitely doesn't suffer from the usual cliches, so I enjoyed talking to everyone I encountered.

The art and the animation is great; everything looks super clear, and is the HD quality we deserve from a 2D game in this decade. I wasn't able to test all of the features yet, but my farming ventures seemed to go fine, and so did the couple of times I tried fishing.

Although I did encounter both major and minor bugs from time to time, from what I've seen, the devs are constantly releasing updates to fix them, and they also respond quickly to questions! The game is in Early Access and still unfinished, but even so, I'm happy with what I've experienced so far, and I'll be waiting on tenterhooks for the full release. Kudos to the developers; keep it up!

If you can get past a few little irks that the game has it's really enjoyable. There's an interesting story, and the farm management is solid. There's very few options for this type of game on PC, and Wild Season does it well. It definitely needs more work, but with time it could be a great game.

The game has a little bit of an issue with the controls, the defaul mapping isn't ideal (however, it can be changed) and it's a little unusual how you have to hold down the key for a little longer than you'd instinctively expect. I've encountered a few minor bugs, but nothing game breaking. There's a few other annoyances, like some animations lasting a little bit too long.

I'd definitely recommend this to anyone who likes this genre of game. However, the game is in Early Access and is not finished yet. This is definitely noticable, so if you're the type that would rather wait for a game to be fully polished and complete then grab it in the future. If you're willing to give it a go right now, and can get past the things mentioned above, you should find it an enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a huge fan of tycoon games and other games that involve some sort of business management, Wild Season immediately interested me. It reminds me of Harvest Moon which is a good thing since those games are amazing. Despite Wild Season currently being only available via Early Access, I can already tell from the little that I have played, that this game is very ambitious and will go very far. Not only does it give you a farm to manage with a quirky back story, but it also includes other various activities around the town for you interact with. In my opinion this gives the town a vibrant atmosphere and makes things feel alive. You are not just limited to a game that revolves around repetitive farming duties like most other similar titles in the genre. You will meet several NPCs around town, all with their own unique personalities and there is also potential for you to meet a person of interest and develop a relationship.

A couple negatives at the moment are the slightly laggy control of the character inventory menu when selecting items and also the character you play seem to move quite inaccurately. I couldn't for the life of me figure out how to save the game as well. Such is the nature of Early Access games so I am sure all these minor issues will be fixed as development continues. I am now eagerly awaiting its final release as I can see this becoming one of those addictive games that I get engrossed with on a daily basis. I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: played during Early Access with a review copy

I like it, but just not enough to recommend it.
First impressions of the game were pretty good; the start screen has a smooth look and there is calm background music. The introduction and beginning of the story nearly hooked me, but there was slightly too much repetition with some of the dialogue.

Options + Controls
The options menu is simple and clean; you can change the sound, and rebind the key controls. While in-game, you can't access the options menu until you receive an item from a NPC. This is a nice idea, but not really user-friendly. The NPCs teach you the basics, but you have to figure out for yourself which buttons to press. It would be nice to be able to move your character around or interact with objects using your mouse, because the controls can sometimes be slightly annoying.

Bugs
Came across a few visual bugs, such as the weather staying grim throughout a couple of summer days,  sometimes NPCs glitch in and out of the doorways, and the response time while fishing is too slow to get a proper result.
Other Problems ...
There are some things that you would expect to be able to do or interact with, but can't. Like being able to place chopped wood where there's an image of a wood pile. Being able to adjust the text speed would also be nice; I accidentally clicked on a few dialogue options when skipping text.

Price
Even with the Early Access discount, I can't help but feel that the price is too high. 3 hours into the game, and I don't feel engaged enough with the story or gameplay to recommend any of my friends to buy it.

My overall impressions of Wild Season is kind of average.
It is in early access, so maybe there will still be features added later on. I want to recommend it, but at the same time I want to shake it like a cassette tape. I'll probably put more time into it, but for now, it's a hit and miss.

First of all, as of now the game is still in early beta stage, version 0.7.0.12 in 8 November 2015. It indeed has quite a few bugs and requires polishing, as the devs themselves state in the store page.

That being said, this is shaping up to be great fun. Everyone who's familiar with the original Harvest Moon on the Super NES will know it as the inspiration behind Wild Season, tho this game aims to go above and beyond. Adding extra skills in the form of cooking, mining and fishing, there are a lot of extra activities to fill up your time after you're done taking care of the crops.

Particularly noteworthy is that it allows your character to be female or male, and the townsfolk include several different eligible bachelors and bachelorettes. Add to it a plot regarding a secret of the town, and it's clear that this has had a lot of effort and care poured into it.

But I feel I must repeat: currently this is still decidedly unfinished, and players are acting as playtesters. If you don't mind bugs and rough edges, you can find a lot of fun, but if you want your game experience unspoiled, I advise waiting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wild Season is a game with a ton of potential. It does a lot of things well, but there is still a lot of work to be done. There aren't many games in its category, so I am happy the developers took the opportunity to make this game.

You start off creating your character. An introduction video tells you who you are, someone who can't find a job. So you decide to buy a farm in the middle of nowhere and start a new life. On your way there you crash your car. Luckily, someone's there to save you and you wake up in the remote town you were headed.

It being in Early Access, there are a lot of problems with the game. But I did find it to be enjoyable during my brief play-through. As I said earlier, a lot is done well. From reading the forums, I have understood that the €28 price mark is a mistake and that the discount price is its 'real' price.

I think this game is great, the entire atmosphere of the game is lovely and there is plenty to do already. But you would have to accept that there is still a lot of work to be done. This game is obviously still a work in progress. So for that, I think €15 is stretching it in its current state. If the game gets to be finished, I would definitely recommend it.

6/10 (taking into consideration it's still EA).

Pros:
+ Get to choose to be male or female, name, birthday and even blood type.
+ Lovely graphics!
+ The musical tracks, albeit monotonous after a while, were very pleasant. I think they fit the game great.
+ Some people have complained about a lot of dialogue, which is true there is a lot of it. But this is a story-driven RPG, it's required for a game like this. I personally enjoyed it a lot. The dialogues and jokes were done really well! Whoever did the writing also had a lot of eye for detail.
+ The game doesn't hold your hand, there's a lot of self-exploration. I think this is great, because games today all have a baby-sitter function. Don't expect that here!
+ During my play-through I felt I had plenty to do. There are a lot of NPCs to interact with, and getting to know better. You can mine for things like ore and diamonds, manage your farm (cut weed, plant seeds, water your plants), and even fishing.
+ Has a neat quest log and journal in one. A World Map that I had to use A LOT. An inventory and your character's profile.
+ Controls for the keyboard are rebindable.
+ There's a toolbar at the bottom of your screen with all of your tools (mining pick, fishing rod, plant seeds, watering can, scythe, hammer and more). The actionbar is binded to numbers so you can equip them without having to go into your inventory.
+ Works with a wireless X360 controller. I thought this played a lot better for this type of game than a KB.
+ Has a stamina system where actions such as mining, drain your stamina and your character becomes tired. This adds a bit of realism and challenge to the game. You can't just spam actions, there are consequences. Your character expresses his/her exhaustion with animations which are very cute, nice job! Sleeping and food help you restore your stamina back up.
+ I like that there's day/night transition, with appropriate crickets sound during night.

Cons:
- Can't adjust your character's physical appearance, such as hair colour. Would be great if this could be added in the future.
- This game REALLY needs a reliable way to speed up text. Whether that's a slider option within the menu (1.5x, 2x etc), or just pressing a button to instantly jump to the end of a conversation bubble. The latter already seems to be in place for the controller. Pressing the A button seems to jump to the end of the bubble? But half the time it just jumps straight to the next bubble, it just doesn't feel reliable enough. Maybe a slider would be a better solution, if pressing a button proves to be too difficult to fine-tune? Or perhaps both, so the players can decide for themselves?
- It happens way too often that controls aren't responding, leading me to bashing the different action keys. For example if I want to start a conversation, or simply cut the weed on my land.
- Talking about cutting stuff, why after scavenging something do I have to press the action key again to put it into my inventory? I assume it's meant to be a choice whether you want to keep the item or not, but I didn't find any way to discard something straight after scavenging. Now all that happens is me running around with an item over my head until I put it into my inventory.
- I feel like the keyboard controls would benefit a lot from the mouse being used more. Also, the game doesn't seem to recognize the mouse cursor that well. For example when saving: http://i.imgur.com/EFPz601.png
- I like that with the controller I can use both the stick and the d-pad, how come the same isn't the case for KB with WASD and arrows? I know you can rebind them, but why not just bind both of them? There are, albeit on rare occasion, moments when I'd like to switch between both. I feel there shouldn't be any issue to simply add this to the game.
- The controls for the controller aren't very intuitive. With some getting used to, they are certainly usable but I found these specifically to be very annoying:
* I couldn't open the main menu, even though start button seems logical. So I had to press ESC on my keyboard instead.
* X to go 'back' instead of B? I find that extremely confusing.
* LB and RB is used to switch between toolbar items, but within the in-game menus I suddenly have to use LT and RT to switch menus? Some consistency here would be nice.
* If I could rebind everything myself it would be fine, but I couldn't find a way to do this for the controller.
- Requires a lot of manual saving to continue where you left off, because loading the automatic save made the game unplayable for me. All I would see is a black screen, forcing me to hard-close the game. Loading my manual saves works fine though.
- That's why it would also be nice if you could save anywhere, and not just by sleeping in your bed. Saves a lot of travelling back and worth (there's a reason why HM02 was invented you know!).
- Meaningless descriptions for the control keys (action1, action2). These really need more meaningful names so you know what you're binding your keys to. Like 'interact' for action1 and 'use item' for action2. These might not be the best either, but it says a lot more than just 'action1'.
- A lot of door glitches, sprite models just running back and forth between doors while talking to you. But I assume these are high on the 'to fix' list.
- The sound of waves in the port, or on the beach, is making me DEAF. Even when all volumes are set to 0%, the volume doesn't change whatsoever.
- I like the addition of the sound of crickets during night, if it weren't for the obvious looping. The looping makes it sound really annoying, I think because it ends so abruptly. I think having a longer track, so the looping doesn't happen every 2 seconds, would help with this.
- Didn't notice any other SFX sounds? I would love for there to be a sound when talking to NPCs, like a lot of other old school RPGs. Maybe even for entering buildings (door sound). Why exactly is there an SFX slider?

Remarks:
* With the keyboard: My character moves faster when sprinting diagonally. I find that this works out pleasantly, because moving around takes a lot of time. But on the controller this does not happen, so I assume it's a bug. I welcome it though.
* With the keyboard: My character sprints automatically in the direction I'm holding, even when I release the sprint key. But considering this does not happen with the controller, this has to be a bug. As someone prone to RSI though, I found this to be very helpful, because it relieves stress from my hand. So I hope this can become an actual feature of the game. (Perhaps a controls option with a check mark that says hold sprint button" so people can choose for themselves?)"

reviewText:
I know there is a lot more to come from this game, but already I love it! I go crazy for anything like Harvest Moon, though I do appreciate that this is NOT Harvest Moon, it is a completely separate game and should be critiqued as such.

I'll start with what is, by far, my favourite thing about this game. The characters. I REALLY like how unique and different each character is from one and other, I find myself getting more and more invested in them and the story the more I play. I find myself feeling differently about certain characters at various points in the plot, maybe suddenly someones motives become clear or even more clouded, maybe they spoke to you slightly differently and your character picks up on it. There's so much going on in terms of plot and people, which makes it a winner in my book. I do however, have one critisism, as you progress and talk to people they might give you clues about what they, or maybe others, like to receive as gifts, I just wish these clues were a little more obvious, and if there are obvious clues, I haven't seen them just yet. Also, I can't end this part without mentioning how happy I am that the Bachelors (and bachelorettes if you roll that way) are so much more age appropriate than in the HM games, I know that you never really get given any ages in HM but just the fact that they LOOK older, it makes my little heart so happy!

Now, I suppose I COULD comment on plot but, honestly, I don't really want to; mostly because I'm still experiencing it for myself but it's also hard to give an honest review of the plot, in my opinion, unless you have seen the whole thing in it's entirety. So far, all I can really say about this games plot is that it sucks you in, stick with it, follow the story, and you'll see exactly what I meant when I wrote about the games characters.

The only glaring problems, for me, are the bugs and keeping in mind this game is still early access, I have to say, they're not actually THAT bad. I mean there are some that really 'bug' me (not even a little sorry for that) but all in all, none are game breaking and I have yet to encounter any that can't be fixed by a simple save + restart. Yeah it's a pain but it's early access! There is one, however, that I havent been able to solve for myself and that is the issues I've been having with the stores, all (barring the animal, general and now Lilly's store) dont actually seem to be interactable, which is annoying because as it stands, I have no way to recover my stamina. I did have the same bother with Lilly initially but that seems to have corrected itself somehow?

All in all, I love this game and if you enjoy Harvest Moon, odds are you will too! I, personally, am enjoying playing it now, as is, BUT don't let the fact that it's not complete put you off, it's a fantastic game with an excellent story and I am addicted!

If you ever sat down in class with a computer, an emulator and a rom of harvest  moon then this game is made for you!! Its an absolute rip off of harvest moon and I couldn't be happier. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excerpt from my blog review on Wild Season:

First off, Harv---I mean, Wild Season has a lot of potential. Since it IS in its early stage, Wild Season is plagued by hilariously wonky bugs and glitches in which I actually I had to stop playing it after 3 or 4 days. However, it shares the same addictive qualities as the beloved Harvest Moon games with, of course, its own spin on it.

What separates Wild Season's storyline from HM is its dark, suspenseful storyline. When you first start, you'll quickly notice that everyone in this town hates you. While the filler of the game is farming, taking care of animals, etc the storyline keeps you hooked to find out the answers and improve your relationships. Wild Season has done a good job on character development giving each NPC unique, intriguing personalities.

One of the unique features of Wild Season is its quest board where NPC's enlist your help by putting up timed errands. Problem is there are just too many bugs and glitches it's almost unplayeable. The funniest glitch that made me laugh was seemingly switching bodies with an NPC in front of me during a quest. Keyboard shortcuts don't register right away so I had to spam a key like 10 times to talk to NPC's.

The game needs a bit more polishing before it's truly ready. Moreover, the way the game is right now doesn't justify its absurdly high price of $30. I would ONLY recommend this game if it's on sale.

Check out the full review on my blog: http://tokyobat.com/harvest-moon-for-pc-wild-season-indie-game-on-steam/

reviewText:
Why does everyone hate this game? Okay, yeah, the controls are a slight annoyance, but if they're that bad for you, you can remap them. Okay, yeah, I don't always agree with the Episodic format. In some siutations it works others it doesn't. All in all, though... I didn't find it too bad.

The few minor glitches I found weren't as game breaking as some would lead you to believe (for me, I had a few instances of things disappearing from my inventory, but upon adding something else to my bags, POOF! it's back). And I never once found the instance of people 'forgetting me'.

That being said, there are a few things that do bug me more then others. The collision detection on some things (ore rocks in the mine, the hit locations for your hoe, axe, sickle, hammer and watering can) can be a mild annoyance, but it's not something that takes away from the soul of the game. That soul is - at it's roots - it's the Harvest Moon we've always wanted. I love Harvest Moon and Rune Factory - it's the whole reason I jumped to buy this game, even before seeing the epidosdic format - and I think that the developers honestly love the series as well. It's Harvest Moon taking place in that seedy little town you're not so sure is as 'upstanding' as everyone says.

On the whole, I think this game has potential - and even though the 'pay for more content' deal caught me completely off guard as I didn't read much past that it was basically Harvest Moon - I will continue to buy the DLC. Some of you will disagree with me, others will agree, but as I stated before, the heart and soul of the game is there... and it is good. A little bit of elbow grease and some love, and this game has the potential to shine brighter then most of the Harvest Moon games, if you'll excuse my pretentiousness.

VERY early access game...one of the earliest. The game probably should not be on Steam's EA yet it is so early in development. And for the current asking price? Absolutely not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review, 11/4/15

Short Version:  A storycentric farming game that seems like it could be fun in the end, but is still too buggy/unpolished in the current Early Access state to really be so now.  I would give a sideways thumb if I could.

Rather than just another flash/facebook farming game, Wild Season is a farming sim with a VN hook. The filler gameplay is much of what you'd expect from a Farming Sim (clearing, planting, expanding, etc), but the storyline adds a reason to continue and grow.  Even as you strive to build up your dusty little rock of a farm into a glowing field of green, much of the focus is on exploring the mysteriously isolated town you have suddenly found yourself a part of.

All in all, Wild Season is a game with promise, but is the very definition of 'Early Access' - multiple bugs are readily apparent (as of 11/4/15) so only buy at this time if you want to support the devs, contribute to the game's progress, or try it out early while builds become more solid.

Current Bugs/Issues:  There are some graphical hitches with character text alternating speeds and animations repeating strangely (characters dashing in-and-out of closed doors several times before they enter), along with various other gameplay bugs. Additionally, the controls still need a great deal of love - it seems to want to be controller-friendly (and given the 3/4 overhead classic rpg feel, it should be), but many controls are not intuitive or simply do not work without a keyboard and mouse - the 9 hotkeys and menus for instance. However, the mouse/keyboard don't feel quite right either, with movement issues and action delays, so you seem to need 4 hands to use all three inputs at once.  Targeting plots on your farm is also a bit of a chore, and character text does not always respond to a button push, which immediately breaks immersion (and makes the many text-boxes in the long intro rather painful to get through).

In the end, Wild Season might be worth a go - but ONLY if you can tolerate early, still-glitchy builds (especially at the current $16 price point, which is high for an unpolished game).  Judging it as a released product, I have to give a thumbs down, but the devs seem to be actively fixing reported bugs and other issues every week, and listening to all feedback given. So, the game may be worth it eventually, but if you want to buy a finished, product to enjoy fully now, you should probably wait until forum topics and recent reviews can confirm a complete, relatively bug-free experience.
